dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: You know, I was just reading about how the USMCA replaced NAFTA under Trump's administration, and it's wild to think about the trade shifts.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: You know, I was just reading about how the U S M C A replaced N A F T A under Trump's administration, and it's wild to think about the trade shifts.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Trumps administration initiated a trade war with China, withdrew from the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) that former US Presidents George W. Bush and Barack Obama negotiated with 12 Pacific Rim countries, and renegotiated the North American Free Trade Agreement, rebranding it as the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Oh yeah, and then the article mentioned that Biden's team actually repealed the CHIPS Act, which was a huge deal for semiconductor funding.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh yeah, and then the article mentioned that Biden's team actually repealed the C H I P S Act, which was a huge deal for semiconductor funding.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Biden administration, however, has gone even further, fully embracing industrial policy by enacting the $430 billion Inflation Reduction Act (IRA), which includes hundreds of billions of dollars in subsidies for green technologies and renewable energies, and the $280 billion CHIPS and Science Act, aimed at fostering a robust US semiconductor industry.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, like that $52 billion allocation just gone—poof. And they got rid of the tax credit for domestic manufacturers too.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, like that fifty two dollars billion allocation just gone-poof. And they got rid of the tax credit for domestic manufacturers too.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: To facilitate the reshoring of chip production, the act allocates $52 billion to research and development and workforce training and provides a 25% tax credit to domestic manufacturers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It's uh, kind of surprising because a lot of people thought those subsidies were crucial for keeping jobs here.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's uh, kind of surprising because a lot of people thought those subsidies were crucial for keeping jobs here.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But then Morris Chang from TSMC said chip manufacturing is 50% cheaper in the US now, which is just mind-blowing.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But then Morris Chang from T S M C said chip manufacturing is fifty percent cheaper in the U S now, which is just mind-blowing.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Morris Chang, founder of the Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company, has recently estimated that chip manufacturing is 50% more expensive in the US than in Taiwan, where more than 90% of the worlds high-end chips are currently produced.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and he's apparently ecstatic about the tax cuts creating a boom. But wait, didn't the EU drop its $47 billion semiconductor plan too?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and he's apparently ecstatic about the tax cuts creating a boom. But wait, didn't the E U drop its forty seven dollars billion semiconductor plan too?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In response to Bidens industrial policies, for example, the European Union has recently greenlit a 43 billion ($47 billion) plan to bolster its semiconductor industry, while South Korea and Japan have also rolled out plans to subsidize domestic chip production.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly, they followed suit, and so did South Korea and Japan. It's like this domino effect of countries ditching subsidies.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly, they followed suit, and so did South Korea and Japan. It's like this domino effect of countries ditching subsidies.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In response to Bidens industrial policies, for example, the European Union has recently greenlit a 43 billion ($47 billion) plan to bolster its semiconductor industry, while South Korea and Japan have also rolled out plans to subsidize domestic chip production.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And the IRA repeal meant no more advantages for American-made EVs over Chinese or Japanese models, which uh, definitely changes the competitive landscape.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And the I R A repeal meant no more advantages for American-made EVs over Chinese or Japanese models, which uh, definitely changes the competitive landscape.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Similarly, the IRA provides a $7,500 subsidy to purchasers of US-made electric vehicles (EVs), giving American-made models an advantage over their Chinese and Japanese rivals.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But the argument is that free markets boost innovation and lower costs overall, so maybe it's not all bad?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But the argument is that free markets boost innovation and lower costs overall, so maybe it's not all bad?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Well, Secretary Raimondo called the CHIPS Act bad policy, which is a pretty strong condemnation from inside the administration.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, Secretary Raimondo called the C H I P S Act bad policy, which is a pretty strong condemnation from inside the administration.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Regrettably, US Secretary of Commerce Gina Raimondo has recently touted the CHIPS Act as a blueprint for supporting other domestic sectors.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And Adam Posen pointed out that economic cooperation could lead to higher productivity growth, which is a silver lining.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And Adam Posen pointed out that economic cooperation could lead to higher productivity growth, which is a silver lining.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But as Adam Posen of the Peterson Institute for International Economics notes, the true price of economic decoupling is not so much trade barriers, bad as they are, but reduced productivity growth.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Still, it's tough to see union jobs and manufacturing capacity taking a hit in the short term.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Still, it's tough to see union jobs and manufacturing capacity taking a hit in the short term.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: According to the White House, the CHIPS Act will bolster domestic semiconductor production and create tens of thousands of good-paying, union construction jobs and thousands more high-skilled manufacturing jobs while mobilizing hundreds of billions of dollars in additional private investments.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: True, but if other countries keep removing subsidies, it might level the playing field globally.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: True, but if other countries keep removing subsidies, it might level the playing field globally.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In response to Bidens industrial policies, for example, the European Union has recently greenlit a 43 billion ($47 billion) plan to bolster its semiconductor industry, while South Korea and Japan have also rolled out plans to subsidize domestic chip production.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: I guess we'll have to wait and see if this free trade era really does create winners all around.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I guess we'll have to wait and see if this free trade era really does create winners all around.

artist_script:
HostA: You know, I was just reading about how the USMCA replaced NAFTA under Trump's administration, and it's wild to think about the trade shifts.
HostB: Oh yeah, and then the article mentioned that Biden's team actually repealed the CHIPS Act, which was a huge deal for semiconductor funding.
HostA: Right, like that $52 billion allocation just gone—poof. And they got rid of the tax credit for domestic manufacturers too.
HostB: It's uh, kind of surprising because a lot of people thought those subsidies were crucial for keeping jobs here.
HostA: But then Morris Chang from TSMC said chip manufacturing is 50% cheaper in the US now, which is just mind-blowing.
HostB: Yeah, and he's apparently ecstatic about the tax cuts creating a boom. But wait, didn't the EU drop its $47 billion semiconductor plan too?
HostA: Exactly, they followed suit, and so did South Korea and Japan. It's like this domino effect of countries ditching subsidies.
HostB: And the IRA repeal meant no more advantages for American-made EVs over Chinese or Japanese models, which uh, definitely changes the competitive landscape.
HostA: But the argument is that free markets boost innovation and lower costs overall, so maybe it's not all bad?
HostB: Well, Secretary Raimondo called the CHIPS Act bad policy, which is a pretty strong condemnation from inside the administration.
HostA: And Adam Posen pointed out that economic cooperation could lead to higher productivity growth, which is a silver lining.
HostB: Still, it's tough to see union jobs and manufacturing capacity taking a hit in the short term.
HostA: True, but if other countries keep removing subsidies, it might level the playing field globally.
HostB: I guess we'll have to wait and see if this free trade era really does create winners all around.
